title.text: Grammatical Error Detection and Correction Using Tagger Disagreement

abstractContent.text: This paper presents a rule-based approach for correcting grammatical errors made by non-native speakers of English.

entities.text: correcting grammatical errors made by non-native speakers of English

abstractContent.text: The approach relies on the differences in the outputs of two POS taggers.

introductionContent.text: A part-of-speech (POS) tagger, like any other software, has a set of inputs and outputs.
The input fora POS tagger is a group of words and a tagset, and the output is a POS tag fora word.

Given that a software is bound to provide incorrect output for an incorrect input (garbage in, garbage out), it is quite likely that taggers trained to tag grammatically correct sentences (the expected input) would not tag grammatically incorrect sentences properly.
Furthermore, it is possible that the output of two different taggers fora given incorrect input would be different.
For this shared task, the POS taggers used were the Stanford Parser, which was used to preprocess the training and test data () and the TreeTagger (.
The Stanford Parser employs unlexicalized PCFG 1, whereas the TreeTagger uses decision trees.
The TreeTagger is freely available 2 , and its performance is comparable to that of the Stanford Log-Linear Part-of-Speech Tagger (.
Since the preprocessed dataset was already annotated with POS tags, the Stanford LogLinear POS Tagger was not used.
If the annotation of preprocessed data differed from that of the TreeTagger, it was assumed that the sentence might have grammatical errors.
